Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Blurry, foggy vision and decreased visual acuity for the past 3 months

Present Illness.Onset: 3 months ago, at home, gradual onset, no specific prodromal symptoms identified. Possible aging-related onset.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Blurry, foggy vision affecting both eyes, progressively worsening over time. Decreased visual acuity, significant especially in low-light conditions. No known relieving factors; glare worsens the symptoms.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Increased glare and halos around lights, occasional monocular double or multiple vision, difficulty seeing in bright light.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Visited optometrist 2 months ago, diagnosed with early-stage cataract. Prescribed new glasses with minimal relief; no other treatments received prior to hospital admission.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Mental state remains stable, with some frustration due to vision impairment. No significant changes in sleep or appetite, regular urination and defecation, stable weight.

Past History.Disease History: No history of systemic diseases or major illnesses
Past History.Infectious Disease History: No history of significant infectious diseases
Past History.Surgery and Trauma History: No previous surgeries or significant traumas reported

Personal History.Living Habits: Non-smoker, occasional social drinker, balanced diet
Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Teacher at a local high school, generally well-lit and comfortable working conditions
Personal History.Exposure History: No significant exposure to industrial toxins, dust, or radioactive substances

Marital History.Children's Condition: Two children, both in good health

Marital and Family History.Family History: Parents deceased, father had hypertension, mother had diabetes; siblings in good health with no similar vision issues reported.

Systematic Examination.Neck: Normal range of motion, no masses or tenderness
Systematic Examination.Chest: Normal thorax shape, clear lung sounds, normal heart sounds, no murmurs

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Ophthalmic examination reveals opacification of the lens in both eyes, more severe in the right eye. Visual acuity: Right eye 20/80, Left eye 20/60. Decreased contrast sensitivity and presence of glare.
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Slit-lamp examination confirms cataract diagnosis with visible lens opacities. No evidence of retinal detachment or other ocular pathology.
Hospitalization Record.Preliminary Diagnosis: Bilateral Cataract, more pronounced in the right eye
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Gradual onset of blurry vision, decreased visual acuity, and ophthalmic examination confirming lens opacities consistent with cataracts.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Glaucoma ruled out due to normal intraocular pressure and absence of optic nerve damage. Age-related macular degeneration ruled out due to normal retinal appearance. Physiological lens aging considered but ruled out due to severity of visual impairment.

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient was admitted with a primary diagnosis of bilateral cataract. Initial examination confirms the presence of significant lens opacities. Plan includes regular ophthalmologic assessments, potential consideration for cataract surgery if visual impairment significantly impacts daily activities.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Day 1: Vision remains stable, patient experiencing slight improvement with adjusted lighting conditions. Day 2: No significant changes, continues to manage glare with polarized glasses.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Dr. Smith reviewed patient on Day 3, agrees with conservative management and consideration for future surgery.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: On Day 4, patient condition remains stable, handed over to Dr. Lee for weekend coverage.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: End of first week: Patient remains stable, vision unchanged. Continues conservative management, no immediate need for surgical intervention.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Ophthalmology consultation on Day 3, supportive of conservative management.
Post-Admission Course Records.Discharge Records: Planned for discharge on Day 7 with follow-up at the ophthalmology clinic in 2 weeks.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: 1. Regular ophthalmologic assessments. 2. Polarized glasses for glare management.

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: Slit-lamp and visual acuity tests confirming cataract presence and severity.
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Temperature, pulse, respiration, and blood pressure within normal limits throughout hospitalization.

Diseases of the Eye and Adnexa.Name: Cataract
Diseases of the Eye and Adnexa.Symptoms: Blurry, foggy vision, decreased visual acuity, decreased contrast sensitivity, blurry vision, monocular double or multiple vision, visual field defects, glare
Diseases of the Eye and Adnexa.Differential Diagnosis: Glaucoma, age-related macular degeneration, physiological lens aging.
